Statements and Blocks

　Statements and blocks are major syntactic components of TJS2.

Statements

　A statement is something that ends with a ; (semicolon). Some consist of an expression followed directly by a semicolon, while others consist of a semicolon following control structures such as if.

Example:
    a++;
    func1();
    return a+b;
    etc.

Blocks

　A block is a collection of multiple statements written between { }. Statements are executed from top to bottom.

Example:
    {
        a++;
        b++;
    }

    {
        var t=func1();
        func2(t);
        break;
    }

　A semicolon (;) is not required after a block.

　Also, every block creates a variable scope.

Execution Order

　In TJS, statements written outside of functions, classes, or properties are executed as the script is run. Statements inside functions, classes, or properties are not executed until they are called.

Example:
    var a; // Executed immediately

    function test()
    {
        a+=10; // Not executed until called
    }

    a+=30; // Executed immediately

　More accurately, class, function, and property definitions are registered first when the script is executed, and then the other script elements are executed from the beginning. Therefore, functions, classes, and properties can be forward-referenced within the same script block.

Example:
    test(); // Functions declared even after this position can be referenced if they are in the same script block

    function test()
    {
        inform("yah!");
    }

　Calling functions between different script blocks is possible as long as the target function has been loaded by the time the call is made.
　Also, variable declarations are processed in the order they are loaded, so forward-referencing is not possible.

Global Object

　The global object is a special object that contains variables, functions, and properties declared at the global level (global scope) as its members. It can be accessed using the "global" keyword.
